channel.title: Burgers on Gourmand Syndrome
channel.description: Recent content in Burgers on Gourmand Syndrome

item.title: Hamburger America
item.description: Hamburger America is a luncheonette-style restaurant with counters for eating a burger. It comes from an American chef George Motz, who is offering an homage to the history of the hamburger. It’s received a number of positive reviews from food critics for some reason, and Yelpers and food bloggers alike rave about this place. I came here as a quick stop around 4:30 PM on a Thursday evening, and I could walk in and sit on the stool without any trouble.

item.title: Revelie Luncheonette
item.description: I was looking for a quick and solo type of restaurant around the Hudson Square area. I decided to look into burgers, and I was debating Hamburger America and this Revelie Luncheonette. This restaurant is walk-in only and is across the street from Raoul’s. Since the burgers seem enticing and the restaurant received decent reviews, I decided to give this a try. I was able to walk in at around 5:30 PM on a Thursday and find an empty stool seat.

item.title: Black Iron Burger
item.description: In the rare occasion nowadays, I am able to sometimes grab dinner solo somewhere. I often debate about the cuisine, and I rarely want to eat something super posh right after work. I noticed a new location of a burger chain opened up. I often confuse the Black Iron Burger with the Blacktap Burger places but not this time. I walked in with no reservations at this 54th and 7th ave location and sat at the bar.

item.title: Au Cheval
item.description: Au Cheval is well known restaurant based out of Chicago. They specialize in elevated burgers and American dishes. When they opened a New York City location, there were crazy lines out the door. The bigger brother to this restaurant is “4 Charles” which specializes in prime rib. Both the burger and prime rib sandwich at Au Cheval are also found at “4 Charles”. I don’t have the patience to book a “4 Charles” reservation and pay the crazy insane prices for steak, so I thought I’d try some of their offerings here. Because they charge $2.49 plus tax, per person, for a reservation on Resy. It’s pretentious, but that did allow us to secure a reservation easily.

item.title: Black Tap Craft Burgers
item.description:
Summary

Typically on the weekends, both this location and the midtown location have a huge line of people waiting outside. And for what reason?

We came on a Friday night around 5 PM, and there were probably at most 3 or 4 small groups of people in a big space.

The cookie shake was a massive vanila-ish shake that had a bunch of sweets on it. It was good, but it is all sugar. I am pretty sure you can finish these shakes by yourself, but that’s just punishing your diet.

item.title: Baroness Bar
item.description: Pretty good albeit expensive. The beer selection here is pretty good.

item.title: Burger Garage
item.description: Reminds me of Pops but more standard burgers. Still pretty good and not too pricey.

item.title: Juanchi
item.description: Pretty good burger if your’e in the area.

item.title: The Spotted Pig
item.description: Burger was OK. Very bleu cheesy. The shoestring fries were annoying to eat and overly salty.

item.title: Chumleys
item.description: Their burger is better than Minetta’s. Nuff said.

item.title: Burger & Barrel
item.description: Got their special $68 white truffle burger. Was good, but not worth it. Don’t spend $68 for white truffles when they’ve practically lose their scent on the plane over here.

item.title: Minetta Tavern
item.description: This is the infamous Minetta Tavern. I had been here back in mid 2010s, and it was pretty good. Before I met my partner, I used to come here once every few months to just scarf their Black Label burger. The price for this was just barely over $20. Now in recent times post-pandemic, it’s been a bit more difficult to walk in without reservations. We were able to sit at the bar on a Friday late-afternoon around 4:55 PM without reservations.

item.title: 5 Napkin Burger
item.description: Overrated. I don’t get why people think this is good. Rather go to Shake Shack or something else.

item.title: Creamline
item.description: Pretty good. I like both the fried chicken and cheeseburger. Probably wouldn’t go here again if it’s out of my way.

item.title: Momofuku Nishi
item.description:
This is suppose to be Italian, but I ate here before they rebranded. They had the Impossible burger here, and it was surprisingly decent.

The red sauce is really good with the fries.

item.title: Buns Bar
item.description: Greasy, but good and filling. I skip the sliders and went straight for the regular burger.

item.title: Bareburger
item.description: Decent gourmet burger. I probably never crave this when I want a burger.

item.title: Mister Dips
item.description:
This place was pretty good. It’s in that Vale hotel.

The waffle fries were good as well as the soft serve.

item.title: Pops
item.description:
One of the best fast-foody burger places in Brooklyn. Cheap, quality, and delish. Cholo is where it’s at. They use Pat La Frieda meats for their burgers, and it’s not too expensive.

Too bad it’s PERMA closed due to rent increase. In place of it is a sex shop.

item.title: Blue Collar
item.description: This place is worse than Pops. Too bad Pops closed down.

item.title: Shake Shack
item.description: I only got a few more NYC eateries to blog about then I’ll be done for now. Shake Shack is basically the west coast’s equivalent to In-N-Out. The one we visited was the original Shake Shack that sits in the middle of some sort of park near Eleven Madison. For a rather chilly day, there was still a long line of people that took approximately 30 minutes for us to get our food. We had time to kill, so why not?
